4427874/4353114/4437751.text:
Long ago clothes were made different from what they are now.  The thread was homespun.  The people sent for the tailor.  He then came, and took all the thread, needles and buttons he needed.  The then sat upon the table with his legs crossed, sewing away.  When he had the suit made, he was paid for it by the people of the house.There was a small tailor in this district.  All the people humbuged him.  He was coming home late one night.  He had an old lantern with him.  The lantern quenched, and then he heard great shouting in a afield close by.  He searched for a match, but before he could find it, the was surrounded by a gang of fairies.

4436845/4384480/4440254.title: Tailors
4436845/4384480/4440254.text: There are no tailors around this locality now but there is a tailor in Ballyboughal named Paddy Swift but he does not do tailoring now. His father before him was a great tailor and used to make clothes for the old R.I.C. His wife used to help him.There is a river this side of Springhill in the townland of Grallagh in Co Dublin called the "Tailors River" because a family of seven brothers named Beaufort lived there.A tailor never wears his boots at his trade but he sits up on the table in his stockinged feet, his legs crossed, and an ironing board across his knees.

4436845/4384481/4440255.title: Tailors
4436845/4384481/4440255.text: The establishment of large boot factories in many parts of Ireland where boots and shoes are made by the most up to date machinery has almost crushed out the old Irish shoe-makerOur grand-father and grand-mother knew little of the present day foot troubles when boots and shoes were made by hand. With rule and tape the shoe-maker took the correct measure of the foot. Then on a wooden last he made the boot or shoe to the exact shape of the foot and so the wearer never suffered from corns or bunions which are the result of wearing badly fitting shoes.The shoe-maker scraped the soles smoothly on the inside with sharp irons and shaped the heel to a comfortable style

Long ago tailors used to go round the country and stop a few days in farmers places tailoring and altering clothes.A tailor named Mr. Cunningham lived in Naul village and died about thirty years ago. She was bedridden with pains. She made the shirts out of cotton, calico and flannelette.Miss Ward who lives in Oldtown knits stockings with a machine. 4428100/4378071/4443751.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428100/4378071/4443751.text: About seventy years ago there lived in the townland of Propogue near the Pike, a tailor named James Colbert who was known as "Little Jimmie the Tailor". He went about from house to house tailoring and he often spent a week in one house making clothes.He was the best tailor in the district at that time. When going making clothes the tailor brought a scissors, thimble, needle and spool, but the people supplied the cloth.His mother had a spinning wheel with which she spun her own thread. it was shaped like a stool with four legs and on the seat a straight stick was placed with a wheel on the top and a small wheel on the other end.When spinning, this woman always sang a song. There were two spinning wheels in the townland of Headboro, one at Mr. O'Connor's and the other at Mr. White's.

4428104/4378288/4445055.title: Tailors
4428104/4378288/4445055.text:
Tailoring is a very ancient trade for it goes back to the downfall of Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. Ever since Adam ate the fruit men have always covered their bodies with some sort of clothing. The most primitive savages use the leaves of trees.In former times there were few tailoring establishments such are to be found today practically in every city and town. In those days the tailor went from house to house seeking work. He brought his outfit with him. This consisted of a heavy pressing iron called a 'goose', a lap-board which was about a yard in length, six inches wide and an inch in depth, a rather big scissors, a tape, divided into inches and tenths, a few short stout needles and a thimble. Unlike a lady's thimble, the tailor's had no bottom. It was just only a band.In farmers houses the tailors usually worked in the kitchen. 4428104/4378299/4445082.title: Why there is no School on Saturday
4428104/4378299/4445082.text: At the time of the hedgeschools, pupils never went for instruction to the teachers on Saturday.  That was the masters washing day, and as he had but one shirt, he had to stay in bed while that was being washed and dried. Tradition has it, that Saturday was a day of brilliant sunshine.   He could not afford to buy a second shirt, as in those days teachers received no salaries but lived on the few pence and halfpence which they received from their pupils.

4428104/4378309/4445122.title: Old Shoemakers
4428104/4378309/4445122.text: A shoemaker here years ago never went to school. When measuring people's feet for shoes he used a piece of twine called wax end. He put a knot for the length of the foot.One day just for fun, some friends of his removed the knot to about two inches larger. He made a very large shoe, big enough for a giant.One night the shoe was stolen and it as said that the fairies took it for the 'Old Woman That Lived In A Shoe'.

4428104/4378349/4445443.title: A True Story
4428104/4378349/4445443.text: A poor old woman lived in Convent St. about fifty years ago. She used to make lace. Every day she travelled the country trying to sell it. Nobody bought the lace because in those days all made lace.One dark November evening when passing the Convent Field she felt something hitting off her heels. She looked behind and saw, as she thought, a nun who threw apples at her.She picked up some but could not take all. She knew the nun's face. As soon as she arrived home she heard that the nun had died during the day.

4427892/4354961/4447052.title: Clothes
4427892/4354961/4447052.text:
There are four tailors in this district. Their names are,Martin O'Brien, James Morley, Thomas Flatley and Thomas Conway. The tailors all work at home. They never for to the houses at all to make anything. The people have to go to their houses with the cloth. Tailors usually have cloth for sale. No cloth is woven in this district now. They have shop cloth for sale always. People never wear locally woven clothes because

4427882/4354171/4447274.title: Churning
4427882/4354171/4447274.text:
(continued from previous page)

In olden times people, especially women and children, left off their shoes for comfort.  Now-a-days one never sees women or men without them.  The children long for the Summer to come until they can leave them off.  There is a family of Flanns living here who never wear shoes and they go round the country begging for alms.  The old people walked to town, and when they got near it they put on their shoes.  They took them off again , going home just outside Webb's shed, on the way home.

4427893/4355325/4447354.title: Folklore - Clothes Made Locally
4427893/4355325/4447354.text:
In this district there are two tailors, Patrick Morley, and Tom Duffy.  Both of those tailors work at their own homes, but they have little work shops built for the purpose.The tailor does not stock cloth and if a man wants to get a suit made he has to purchase the material himself, but the tailor has patterns, and he sends off for the material, if the person wants it.The tailor does not travel round to the houses as formerly, those were called "journey men." 4427882/4354172/4447689.title: Care of the Feet
4427882/4354172/4447689.text:
There are numerous customs observed in this district.  When washing feet, for instance, young children wash their toes first, because their toes are the lowest part of the feet, and the old people say that if they begin at the low position they will keep advancing in their station of life.  The boys in this district usually take off their shoes during the Summer months, but adults, with the exception of some tinkers , do not take them off.

Our Lord was displeased at that and He told her to stay the night with the dead man.  Then she went into the house and He went on to the next village.  The next morning Our Lord came back for her
(continues on next page)

There is one tailor in our district.  He always works at home in his workshop.   He does not stock material.  His customers buy material in Ballyhaunis and take it to him.  No cloth is spun or woven here now but some was, three or four years ago.  No people in this district wear home-spun materials.   A tailor uses a sewing machine, two pressing irons, a needle, a thimble, a card of soap, a basin of cold water, a clean cloth, and clothes brush and a basting ripper.   Women who are sewers make shirts and trousers for boys at home.  They buy the cloth for the shirts in town and they make the trousers out of men's old trousers.  Some women knit socks

4428081/4376256/4447956.title: Éadaí
4428081/4376256/4447956.text: Mr. Martin Deacy, Lisduff parish of Templmore, Barony of Gallen and in the Co. Mayo, is the tailor in my district.The people do not weave cloth now but they did so long ago. There are no túinne to be found in this district but it was not so long ago. The people in my district knit stockings and they buy the thread from the shopkeepers.

4427895/4355691/4448258.title: Clothes
4427895/4355691/4448258.text:
A great many people wear home-made clothes. The people themselves knit home-made stockings and shirts. Before the women make the stocking the thread is spun. First the wool is prepared for spinning. It is oiled and teased out and then it is carded with a pair cards and it is made into rolls. After that it is spun with a spinning wheel. There is a band going round the spinning wheel and it is joined to the spinnle and she starts spinning. When she has a few pairs of stockings knitted she colours them. When she has the stockings made she makes more thread. All the spinning wheel is made
(continues on next page)

4427895/4355692/4448259.title: Clothes
4427895/4355692/4448259.text:
(continued from previous page)
of wood. The spinning-wheel is very useful in the home.



My mother often made shirts out of flour bags for us children. She also made then out of flannelette, and out of swanskin. She also knitted socks or stockings as some people call them. She makes the stockings yet. She teases the wool first and oils it and then she cards it and makes rolls of it. Then sets the spinning wheel and forms it into thread. She keeps on making the thread until she has enough for a few pairs fo stockings. Then she
(continues on next page)

4427895/4355693/4448260.title: Clothes
4427895/4355693/4448260.text:
(continued from previous page)
makes the stockings and when she then made she colours[?] them if they are white stockings. When she has the stockings made she makes more rolls of wool and then she makes more thread. The spinning wheel is a good article for making thread. There is a band round the wheel and it is tied on the spindle. It is made of woollen thread and it makes the spinning wheel go round.



When the people are going to make shirts they go to a drapes[?] shop to buy the material. The makings of the shirt is cut out first then

4427898/4355845/4448826.title: Clothes
4427898/4355845/4448826.text:
There are six tailor's in the parish. They work at home in their houses. The tailors do not sell cloth. The cloth is bought in the shops. The implements the tailor uses is a thimble, sewing machine, scissors, needles, an iron, a measuring tape. long ago the people made shorts out of flour bags. Spinning wheels were used in the place long ago. Stockings are knitted in the place. Some people buy the thread in shops for knitting stockings. Flax was grown in the place long ago. Every house in the parish had a spinning wheel long ago. When they used to have the wool psin the used to sell some of it.



There are five tailors in the parish.
(continues on next page)

4427874/4353135/4449174.title: Béaloideas Éireann - Tailors
4427874/4353135/4449174.text: Tailors are men who make suits. They are very common in this country. They make the suits in their own house now. Long ago they went around from house to house to make the suits.They came to the house. They brought the scissors, a thimble, and a needle with them. They took up the kitchen table and sat there for a week.If the people were wealthy he took his time in making the suit. If the people were wealthy he took a fortnight or three weeks to make it but if the people were poor he hurried with it and went on to the next because the food wasn't good. Tailors are very much respected now.

There were no clocks in this part then.



Bog deal was got in Bloomfield Bog and Cluancaocháin.  Burke, relative to Lord Mayo, lived in Cluancaocháin Castle.



There were very few carts then.  Stones for the present Roundfort Church in Pardóga.  They were brought from Routledges Quarry.  One man from Purranes had an old cow drawing a half-door with two stones on it.  The cow died at Sullivan's (the Hedge School).



Hides of sheep, with the wool pulled off, made trousers.  When wet, it got so long, that it went down to the feet.  When it dried with the fire, it got short and only stretched as far as the knees.  Corduroy was the whole go then, especially for trousers.

Frieze was used for men's coats. Wool was carded at  home and woven into frize in Carrakeel by the weaver Richard Conry. (This was Riocard uabpaidreacha wo used to teach Catechism of Sunday's in the church.



The Tailor came around from house to house He came after the cutter. The cutter was Séamus Ó Confhaola. He was called Fear an T-rioruna. The tailor sat on a door left flat on the ground. Three tailors made a suit in one day. They charged 4/- for making a suit. The master-tailor cut and the journey-men sewed. He took all the remnants with him. N.B. John Merrick pronounced this word "remlets"



There was no shoe-maker but one in this locality. He was Brian Hynes of Ballinrobe. He was grandfather of John Hynes, shop-keeper Main-St. Castlebar.



Flax was grown in the locality  (1870). and spun into linen. "Tuairne eiteáin" was the name given to the flax wheel The woollen wheel would not spin flax The shirts were all hand made by the women
(continues on next page)

4427877/4353327/4449285.text:

The shirts in these days lasted seven to ten years.



All hats worn by men were tall-hats. A man left his measure with Michael Heron Ballinrobe. He lived in the corner house where Mr. Bernard Joyce. Co. C., lives now. The hats were manufactured and made in Manulla near Balla Co. Mayo.



Masons.There was a mason in every village.



There were two carpenters in Roundfort: Michael Costello and Myles Deasy. They used to make wooden plows and have them on show for sale every Sunday



Nails were made in Hollymount by a nailor, named Thomas Dwane He lived where Thomas Connor is living now. He made nails from the backs of old scythes. He used to wear a paper cap when working. The shoe-maker in Ballinrobe, Brian Hynes, used to call for the nails used in men's shoes. They were very heavy nails.

The ruins of an old forge are to be seen near.  Keanes house in Crumlin.  It belongs to Michael Bourke who died 4 years ago.



Mr Raftery made gates for the local people.  If anyone was getting married he usually brings a blacksmith to the wedding.  If not it is said he would have no luck.

4427847/4350260/4449620.text:
(continued from previous page)
Woman generally wear dresses made from linen and overalls made from branched cotton.

He used to go to any house where there was work to do for him.  He used to make suits for any one who would buy cloth for him. Mrs Sheridan Mrs Griffith and Miss Corcoran sells cloth but Miss Keane does not.

4427896/4355155/4449983.title: A Clever Fellow
4427896/4355155/4449983.text:
In olden times when a person needed clothes to be made they had to send for a tailor to come to the persons house and do the work there.There was a certain man and his wife and they sent for a tailor because they wanted him to make a suit.  The tailor got up early and he set out without his breakfast as he thought that the woman of the house would have his breakfast ready when he got there.But when he reached the house the people had already eaten their breakfast and were all at work.The tailor got the material and cut it and had it all prepared for sewing and he thought the woman of the house would prepare a meal for him but she didn't as she thought he had it already eaten.When the tailor saw what was going on he stood up and walked out and went up some distance the road and then

4427896/4355172/4450005.title: Éadaí
4427896/4355172/4450005.text:
Éadaigh.Fadó nuair a (bhí) culaith éadaigh ag na daoine. (Tháinig) an tailliúir o teach go teach agus (thug) na daoine loistín agus bia do agus ansin ní (raibh na héadaí) ró-daor. Bhí na daoine cneasta (do). Dúirt mo seanathair (dom) go raibh níos mo tailliúra sa cheantar seo fadó. Nuair a (bhí) obair le déanamh ag na daoine agus cuir siad (glaoch) ar an tailliúir (agus rinne an táilliúir na daoine a thomhas). Nuair (a thóg sé an thomhas chuir sé an culaith eadaigh ar an mbord. D'íoc na daoine air chun an) culaith eadaigh a dhéanamh. An ainm (a bhí) ar (na héadaí)Bréidín no plainnín.Bhí (triúr) táilliúir sa cheantar seo.
(continues on next page)

4427886/4354408/4450585.text: In olden times people used to be over thirty years of age before they ever wore boots.  Over one hundred and fifty years ago there lived a man by the name of John Rushe and he never wore a boot.  Certain people in the village never wore a boot, because they thought when boots came out first they thought that the were traps and if the people put them on, they thought that they would not be able to take them off. Ever since a smiths right hand will never get tired. On winter nights a crowd come to the forge to play cards. Sometimes in summer they play pitch and toss. The forge was never figured in any historical event.Kitty Quann, Ballyshuneen, Dunmore East, Co Waterford.  Got from my father.



There is no tailor in this district. Shirts are not made at home. Long ago people used to grow flax and Mr. Cotter used to weave it. Stockings are knitted in every home. The thread is not spun at home. It is bought in the shops. No one has spinning wheels in this district. Black clothes are worn for six months when a relative is dead and black and white is worn for the other six months.

4428212/4386094/4452838.title: Travelling Folk
4428212/4386094/4452838.text:
(continued from previous page)
When they have collected all they can get, they meet at a certain place and from there, start off for the next town.  Sometimes they have twenty to thirty caravans and it is mostly children and young boys who look after these.



The Famine.---The famine is believed to have affected this district very much. The potatoes decayed in the ground and afterwards when the men went to open their pits full of potatoes they also were ruined. The following year they had no seeds to sow, so they put down the skins of old potatoes. But these only turned out to be just the size of a marble. The only food the people had then was Indian meal & yellow turnips; with the result that many people died of starvation. After this the Cholera & smallpox broke out among the people (through starvation & bad food, nobody got Government Relief here & so the people died in great numbers.



Care of the feet.Most of the boys in former times did not wear boots until they went to work.  When going to school, either in winter or summer they went bare-footed. Even girls went bare-footed 40 years ago, but they do not go like that now.Boots are made & repaired in Lucan by three bootmakers.  Mr Dempsey (main street)was the only one for 60 years ago.  Leather was never made in Lucan neither were clogs worn.

Mrs Rodgers, 50, Raherolish, Kilmovee, Ballaghaderreen, Co Mayo.In my district there is a garden which they call Garradh na featherman. This garden belonged to an old man who had alittle hut in it. Day by day he went round the district gathering feathers. He made ederdown quilts and cushions and sold them in the town. In this way he made his living. The little hut is not to be seen now for there is a heap of stones in its place. The garden is now called Garradh na featherman.This garden is owned by Patrick Dalton, Raherolish, kilmovee, B'Derreen, Co Mayo.

4427827/4347877/4453942.title: Clothes
4427827/4347877/4453942.text:
There were three tailors in the parish long ago. Their names. Their names were James Mullanie, Patrick Gibbons and Mrs. Gibbons. James Mullanie used go from house to house working for people. He used not keep the cloth in the house. It was mostly farmers that wore the suits he made. The suits were made out of frieze and tweed.The things a tailor used when making a suit are a needle, thread, scissors and an iron. Some of the tailors also made shirts. They made them out of flannel and linen. When anyone wanted a suit made for them they
(continues on next page)

4427922/4357952/4454085.title: Clothes Made Locally
4427922/4357952/4454085.text:
There are only two tailors in this district. Mr Michael Flannery Tonroe, Carracastle, Ballaghadereen Co. Mayo, and his son James. Jim Flannery's father and grandfather were tailors. He learned his trade from his father. They work at their homes and do not travel from house to house as they used to formerly. Cloth is not spun or woven locally but it was long ago in Castleduff. Socks and stockings are knitted locally by the old woman. Thread is not spun in the homes nowadays. There is only one spinning wheel in this district and it belongs to Mr. Ned Parsons, Tonroe, Carracastle, Ballaghadereen. Co. Mayo. It is not used now. Shirts
(continues on next page)

4428068/4374791/4455159.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428068/4374791/4455159.text: I have some bed sheets of my mother's handwork in the house yet. She lived in Cruggane in the parish of Backs. It is about eighty years since she them. She grew the flax herself, and prepared it for the weaver. Then she sent it to Mr. Merrick, who resided in Ballina, and he wove it into linen. Later he emigrated to America, and died a few years ago.

4428068/4375119/4455192.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428068/4375119/4455192.text:
Fifty years ago, I had a spinning wheel of my own. I used to card wool and spinn it into thread. Then I would take it to the weaver to be woven into cloth. I grew flax in my own land, scutched it and spun it into thread. When that was done, I would take it to the weaver to be woven into linen. I have a sheet and blanket of my own handwork yet. It was woven by Malachy Kelly., Lisaniska, Knockmore, Backs, Co. Mayo.
(continues on next page)

4427829/4348090/4455886.title: Seancheirdeanna
4427829/4348090/4455886.text:
[???]My grandfather Owen McCormac was a weaver long ago.  He wove blankets and flannels for nearly every family from here to Burren Mor and also in the parash [sic] of Addergoole.The women used to spin their own wool and bring it to him to weave it.  One woman asked him if he could make it a bit wider than the usual width so that she could roll the child beside her in bed.At first he used to charge three shillings a blanket and after that he raised the price to seven shillings a blanket.This is how the weaving was done, first all of the sheep wool was shorn off the sheep.  Then it was made clean and washed.  After that it was carded and spun, one part which was called the warp was spun finer than the weft.  It took about seventeen lbs of wool for a homemade blanket.
(continues on next page)

Then, all the people dance round the May Pole singing songs and playing games. On May Day, some people do not put ashes or water out of their houses.



A shawl is a loose covering made of various materials for the neck and shoulders.	A shawl is made of silk, wool, cotton, hair, and chasmere. The wool is got from the sheep, the silk from the silk worm, and the hair is clipped from the horse and camel and cotton is obtained from the cotton plant, which grows in hot countries.	Woollen shawls are manufactured in Paisley and Scotland, cotton in England and South America, cashmere shawls in Asia while in France and Spain lace and silk shawls are obtained. In the manufacture of shawls, looms are employed and some shawls are, when woven embroidered in various ways. Woollen shawls are worn by old people, cashmere shawls by European Queen’s, camel hair shawls are worn by Indian Princesses, while the wealthy are to be seen wearing lace or silk shawls.

4428149/4382009/4458396.title: Clothes
4428149/4382009/4458396.text: Tailors lived in every parish in years gone by. The tailors I heard of in this parish were Billy Power Bawnfawn who was nicknamed Billy the tailor. There was another tailor in Lisnakill and another lived in Sporthouse. There were dressmakers lived in this parish also. Long ago when a person would be getting clothes made by a tailor, the tailor would come and stay in the house. Some people used make their underwear with unbleached linen. The women of the house used knit all the socks and stockings. Friends or relatives of a dead person used wear white lands around their hats at a funeral. Sometimes when a girl would get married, her mother would give her a hooded cloak as a gift.

Redcross.It will afford pleasant variety to give a few anecdotes relative to a Mr. Daniel Byrne, a tailor ancestor of Lord de Tabbey. He used to buy all the white cloth in Dublin and get it coloured red and clothed 40,000 men with same for Cromwell and never called for the money until all was finished and then received drafts from Cromwell on the Treasury when he got cash with which he purchased the estates. People began to wear boots in former times at the age of twenty years. There are accounts of people who never wore boots or shoes. Catherine Gavin Ballyheane and Bridget Mc. Donnagh never wore boots. Children at present go barefoot in Summer time but they have shoes on them the rest of the year.The water that is used for washing the feet is usually thrown out but some people put it on flowers. They say it helps them to grow.Boots are repaired locally but they are not made. There are two shoemakers in the district. Martin Joyce Errew, and Michael Deasy Errew. It has been a tradition in the family. There are more shoemakers now than long a go because there are more booths worn at [?] present.Clogs are still worn but they are not made locally. They are worn by the children and old people.

4428274/4390750/4459072.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428274/4390750/4459072.text: There is one tailor in this district. He works in his own home and does not travel from place to place. When people want clothes made they go to the tailor and he takes their measure and then makes the clothes for them. The implements that the tailor uses are a spool and needle and scissors and tape and sewing machine.Socks and stockings are knitted locally. There are no spinning wheels in this district now.

When Our Lord and His mother were going to Jerusalem to celebrate the feast of the Passover, some years after Saint Joseph had died the darkness darkness approached earlier than usual. They weren't as far as their usual resting place, so the only thing to do was to seek shelter in the nearest farmer's house. They went into the house and they found that the people were very pure. The woman had a pot full of water on the fire. She told Him that she had no food for the children but that she put down the pot so that they might think it was their supper. Our Lord then told her to take the cover off the pot and when she did so she saw that it was full of potatoes. They ate them and after that they lay down for the night's rest. Next morning Our Lord and His mother went away

4428073/4375237/4460861.title: Clothes
4428073/4375237/4460861.text:
There are four tailors in the parish now. They work in their own houses. They keep some cloth in their houses and some people buy them cloth and get them to make it. It is shop-cloth the tailors generally use in their houses now.Long ago the people wore suits of the cloth they made at home which was called "Flannel". We knit stockings at home. My mother spins the thread on a wheel called the linen wheel. There is a spinning wheel in every house in the district. There are two sorts of spinning wheels in my district, One is called the woollen wheel and the other is called the linen-wheel. The woollen wheel is generally used for twisting thread and the linen-wheel is generally used for spinning thread for stockings and for spinning thread for making blankets.People wear special clothes on special occasions such as when a person dies that persons friends wear

4428111/4379105/4462622.title: Tailors
4428111/4379105/4462622.text: There no tailors in Clashmore and there is only one dress-maker. The tailors do not make the clothes in the customer's houses but in their own workshop. The tailors do not sell the clothes but the customers buy it in a Draper's shop and thread and give it to the tailor. A tailor very seldom makes shirts but only suits and other clothes. He works with scissors, a sewing machine, tape, thimble, thread, marking chalk and many other things. A few old women knit stockings but only for the family. The thread is bought in Youghal. There are no spinning-wheels around here now.

4427943/4360005/4462746.title: Old Crafts - Colouring
4427943/4360005/4462746.text: In the olden times, the people used to colour woollen [sic] stockings with the moss that grew on the walls.  When they would have the stockings ready to colour they would wet them in cold water put them into a pot of water alongwith the moss and boil them together.  When they were taken out they were a brown colour.  Then they washed the stockings and put them out to dry.

4427943/4360007/4462748.title: Old Crafts - Dyeing
4427943/4360007/4462748.text: Long ago when people wanted to dye clothes they pulled moss off the stones, they put it into a cloth, put it into a pot, which they put down on the fire to boil, and put whatever they wanted to dye down along with it.  When they took it up it was coloured brown.If they wanted to dye clothes red, they bought madder in the shop, put it into a cloth, put it down on the fire to boil in water, put what ever they wanted to dye down along with it and when they took it up it and washed it, it was dyed red.

4428062/4373956/4463510.title: Footwear
4428062/4373956/4463510.text:
Long ago the people where not accustomed to footwear such as we have now.   They had no boots or shoes or clogs but they wore woollen stockings.A good many people wear clogs now especially farmers.   They are very warm foot wear.   Clogs were worn in England before they were worn in this country.   The men going to England wore them there and then they were brought to Ireland.A good many farmers are able to make a pair of clogs.    Some farmers make clog soles;   then they

"Táim chead bliain d'aois" arsa sé "agus dá mbeinn bliain eile gheobhainn siúl". Bhí abha mór ag gabháilt leastiar d'áitreabh na bhfathach seo. Dúirt an scoláire leis an leanbh go dtabharfadh sé amach é. Thug agus caith sé an cliabhán agus an páiste leis an abhainn. D'iompaigh an páiste air agus dúirt "É  a mhic a rí ó Éire níor láir duit an obair atá déanta agat". Tháinigh sé isteach agus chuir culaith catha air. Bhí culaith catha ag crocadh taobh thiar de gach aon each a bhí sa stábla. Tiomán sé a cuid ba abhaile agus d'fhág sé fén bhfeirmeoir agus a bhean tighe iad a crú. Tháinigh an scoláire thar nais go dtí áiteabh na bhfathach agus sin é mo scéal agus má thá bréag ann, bíodh.

4463715/4374175/4463887.title: Clothes Made Locally
4463715/4374175/4463887.text:
There is only one tailor in my district and his name is James Mac Neela.   He is living at the north side of Nephin, in the village of Ballymacredmond, about a mile from Lahardane.He is staying with his sister, Mrs Jack Mangan, who is a dressmaker and who assists him in the making of men's clothes when he is busy, but he does all the cutting.He does not travel from house to  house as tailors did formerly but works in his own house.    He is regarded as a good tailor and is kept very busy.   He stocks cloth both serge and tweed.   The principal implements he uses when working are, sewing machine,
(continues on next page)

4463715/4374178/4463889.title: The Local Dressmaker
4463715/4374178/4463889.text:
There is one dressmaker in this district and her name is Mrs Mangan.   She lives in the village of Ballymacredmond about one mile west of Lahardane.She does not deal in cloth herself but she has a pattern book and she will send for the cloth you select and have it back in a few days.She makes dresses-frocks and costumes,-coats, and underwear for women and children.The charge is very reasonable - about 5s for a full-sized frock and 6s.6d for a costume.She turns out good work
(continues on next page)

4463715/4374183/4463892.title: Clothes Made Locally
4463715/4374183/4463892.text:
In this district many women knit most of the clothes required for their household such as cardigan, jumpers, caps, gloves, scarfs and socks.   Some women spin the thread, while others buy it in  a shop.   Carding, spinning and knitting is done mostly in the winter when the nights are long.There are four spinning wheels in our neighbourhood all of which are small.Some handy women make under-clothes for men and for their children and the material they generally use is flannel.There was a knitting industry recently established in Lahardane, Co.Mayo, by Miss Durcan, and I am informed the machine cost £40.
(continues on next page)

4427952/4360530/4464105.title: Clothes
4427952/4360530/4464105.text:
On Friday night last when I was visiting in Mrs Dunleavy's she told me all about the clothes the people used to wear when she was a little girl.  She is ninety two years of age and lives in the village of Derryronane Swinford.   There was only one tailor in this locality named Duffy. He used to live in a little village called Shamer about three miles from Derryronane. At that time when the boys used to get new suits the tailor used to come to the house to get the measurements and stay while making them. They had not any sewing machines and on that account it used to take them about three weeks to make a suit. The women used to spin the thread and dye it with log wood and they used to send the flax to Ballina to get it bleached.
(continues on next page)

4427952/4360573/4464239.title: Clothes
4427952/4360573/4464239.text:
ClothesLast night I had another chat with my mother about the clothes in olden times.  She lives in Carracanada, Swinford and is about 45 years of age.  She got it from her grandmother when she was a little girl.  There are no tailors in the district now.  Tailors now work at their own homes but long ago the tailors used to go around to the houses and make the clothes. They used to spend a few days doing so.  The tailors now stock bales of cloth.  Cloth is not now spun very much locally.  There are many types of cloth and here they are tweed, corduroy, frieze and serge.  The tailors when making clothes uses these implements scissors needles chalk a tape and irons.  The people make shirts in the
(continues on next page)

4427945/4359965/4465388.title: A Blacksmith and His Forge
4427945/4359965/4465388.text: There are two forges in this parish.  The man that works in a forge is called a blacksmith.  The names of the blacksmiths that work in those forges are John Dunleavy and Michael Jordan.  The forges are both situated on the side of a road where a stream passes by.  A door of a forge is very wide like that of a garage.  There is one fireplace inside in the forges.  He shoes horses mules and asses.  He makes ploughs harrows spades shovels picks and axes.  The principal instruments used by the smith are a hamaner, bellows, anvil.  There is a story told about our blessed Lady.  She was once going by a forge and she wanted a pen.  The smith came out and offered to make one for her.  She then expressed thanks.  He took a piece of silver from his pocket and made the finest brooch that was ever made.  Ever since then a smith who washes in the water which has cooled his irons finds himself refreshed and made stronger.  A blacksmith is always supposed to be a strong muscular man.  Every night a crowd of men gather to the forge, for the blacksmith has always old takes to tell them.

4427945/4359966/4465389.title: A Tailor
4427945/4359966/4465389.text: There are two tailors in this parish.  There was one in it about six months ago.  His name was James Martin King.  He is living at Knock now about six miles away.  A tailor has a good many articles in his shop.  He has a good many needles a sewing machine a big table and a thimble and scissors.  He has a big piece of iron called "the goose".  It is an old saying that a tailor has never a good suit of clothes.  First a tailor gets the material and makes the clothes.  There are patterns hanging on the walls and you may choose any one you like and the tailor will make one like it for you.  Some of the women spin thread and knit stockings.  The women spin wool with a spinning wheel.  John Deacy, Pat Kelly, and Shiels have spinning wheels.  There is not any weaver around here.  A weaver makes a blanket for ten shillings.

4427961/4361204/4465890.title: Clothes
4427961/4361204/4465890.text: There is but one tailor in this parish.  He mends clothes and makes clothes.When a person wants a new suit of clothes he goes to the tailor.  When he reaches the tailor-shop he chooses a piece of cloth.  Then the tailor takes his measure and he marks out the suit.  Then he cuts out the suit and [?] it.  After a few days the man who is getting the suit made returns to the tailor he fits the suit on the other man.  Then he sews the suit.

4427961/4361212/4465895.title: Tailors
4427961/4361212/4465895.text: There are two tailors in this district. When a man has a suit to make. He goes to the shop and chooses a nice pattern. Then he goes to the tailor and he takes his measure and makes his suit. Almost every person leaves his measure for a suit, Tailors are very scarce nowadays. You will get ready made suits now in the shops for fewer and higher prices. Tailors also make boy suits and overcoats. They take their measure and when the suit is made he tells his charge.

4428056/4373339/4467100.title: Composition
4428056/4373339/4467100.text:
Long ago the people wore no shoes. Then they were very hardy and never seemed to be cold. Now it is a strange thing to see a person without his Shoes all the year round.	Nowadays the people suffer from various diseases caused by the shoes. Almost half the world suffer from “corns” or bunions or chilblains on their feet. When the people were going without their shoes the hadn’t to suffer from corns or any other disease.	The most comfortable and softest shoe is made from the skin of the calf or the skin of the seep. 4427987/4364335/4467936.title: Muileann
4427987/4364335/4467936.text:
Muleann 13-4-1938About sixty year ago, There was a miller named Jack Heveron in the upper part of the Glenamoy river. He had a mill for grinding Oatmeal and for thin thickening flannel and all kinda of woolen goods. The mill was driven by water. He was a native of Achill bo Mayo. He brought his Querno from Achill by a horse and cart into the village of Bunalty. He set his mill close to the Lylenamoy river. He had no home of his own, he used to lodge in Leanaragh and Shranaploya in different houses. one or two days in each house. He was only charging three pence per hundred for grinding the oatmeal, and for thickening flannells. He closed down the mill after a few years and went to his native village.
(continues on next page)

4427987/4364343/4467967.title: (no title)
4427987/4364343/4467967.text: Long ago there lived in the town-land of Kilgalligan, a man named Dermot McCormack. He was a shoe-maker by trade. At that time there was a scarcity of leather, and leather could not be got any nearer than Castlebar. One Summer's morning he set off for Castlebar travelling on foot, bought seven stone of leather (and) put it on his back and carried it to Kilgalligan and was there at night-fall.Scoláire. 4428050/4372232/4468245.title: The O'Dowds of Ardnaree
4428050/4372232/4468245.text: Long years ago there lived in Ardnaree a man named O'Dowd who owned the street. One day the O'Dowd was asked to a big party in Dublin and he was in a terrible state as he had no dancing shoes, so he went to a neighbour called O'Sullivan and asked him for the loan of his shoes. After a while the man said he would give them to him but before he gave them he made a bargain that the shoes would have to be returned before a certain date or if not Ardnaree would be his.  The O'Dowd went off with the shoes and did not return so from that day to this there was never known an O'Dowd to live in Ardnaree.

There were many tailors in this district long ago. There was a tailor in Louisburgh named Mr Maxwell and they was a tailor in Accony West named Brian O Malley. He was called Brian Sheáin Táilúir. He used to go from house to house making clothes. He used to make Frieze suits flannel suits drawers and bainíns and all sorts of things like that. Mr Maxwell had his own house in town and the people used to send him whatever they were getting made. The tailors had no machines long ago. They used to sew with a needle thread and a thimble. The people used to make linens long ago. They used to sow flax and when ripe it was pulled and steeped in a bog hole. Then it was lifted and spread on the grass to bleach. When bleached it was tied up and made into shaves. When sheaved it was brought in to dry at the

4428046/4371866/4473782.title: How Frieze was Made
4428046/4371866/4473782.text: How Frize was made 8-6-1938The material used by most country people in this district for making coats and froks sixty years ago was frieze. It was made by the farmers wives, and had to undergo many operations. The wool was dyed and then carded and spun along the kitchen fire during the long winter nights. At that time the women helped the men at the laborious work on the farm during the day. The yarn was sent to the weaver to be woven into cloth, and Mr. Peter Reilly Garden St. Ballina then was in much request with his hand loom He was the only weaver in this district.The woven material was then taken home and washed or "scoured" and was then dried. It was sent to a Mr. Brogan who lived on the shore of the Attymass lake to be "thickened". Then the cloth was sent to a Mr. Wall, Hill St, Ballina, to be "pressed". It was taken to the tailor to be made into coats and froks.                              P.J. TimlinAuthor - Patrick TimlinFaranascullogue

4428002/4366677/4473884.title: Clothes
4428002/4366677/4473884.text: There are three tailors in the parish. They live in Bangor Erris. Their names are Anthony Barrett, James Barrett and Edward Carey. They do not go from house to house. They usually work at home. It is not usuall for a tailor to have clothes in the house to sell. He does not make any clothes until they are measured for.There are not many spinning  wheels in the place. Some of the people knit their stockings.

4428040/4371300/4473987.title: Forges
4428040/4371300/4473987.text:
(continued from previous page)
James Collins, Foghill, had a forge in Castle Rea yard Killala and in Carn yard. He had another in Palmerstown with his own in Foghill. He used to work three days of the week in Foghill, and three days in the Palmerstown forge, one day a month in Carn, and one in Castle Rea.



There are two tailors in our parish. Mr. O'Conner in Kilcummin and Mr. McHale in Killala. Those tailors make suits, coats and costumes. They do not keep the cloth, they buy it. They are very skillful tailors.
(continues on next page)

4428019/4368559/4474113.title: The Cléithín
4428019/4368559/4474113.text:
(continued from previous page)
the glass catches the flesh and helps to draw it up.



This is how brown dye is made. They get scrartcloch [|?] off the rocks in the fields. They scrape the scraitcloch off the rocks with a knife. They boil it in a pot and they put onion peels through it. Then they put in whatever they have to dye. When it is boiling an hour they lift it and wash it in hot water and they leave it out to dry. Then it has a good brown colour.



The feár gortach stone is a stone on the left hand side of the road beyond Kilsallagh School. There is a track of a crow's foot on the stone and the old people tell us that if a person sat on it they would get
(continues on next page)

4428019/4368561/4474117.title: (no title)
4428019/4368561/4474117.text:
To take the top off a boil they used to get a bottle with a wide sgluig. They put a little drop of water in the bottle and placed the bottom of it near the fire. When a little steam was seen round the bottle it was placed sgluig downwards on the boil and it lifted the boil off completely.



Long ago the women used to dye the wool black and make cloth out of it. They used to get airgead lóchra[?]. This is a white flower that grows plentifully along hedges. They boiled this for hours in a pot. It coloured the water a brown colour. This was called bark. When it was well boiled they strained off the water put it back into the pot again. They put the wool into it and also a substance called "bog ink". They got the "bog ink" in a certain place in the bog. This gave a good black colour to the water and a lasting dye to the wool.
(continues on next page)

4428021/4368739/4474356.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428021/4368739/4474356.text: There are no tailors in this district.

4428041/4371596/4474496.title: Tailors
4428041/4371596/4474496.text:
Long ago there were three tailors that used to sew by hand, and they used to go about to any body that would bring them. Their names was Anthony Hoban, foghill, Peter Summers Steelaun, Paddy Williams Rathlacken, Carrowmore, Ballina,Co. Mayo, R.I.P.The people themselves that used to buy the cloth, then they used to send for the tailor, and he’d come and take the measure of the person. He used to have a big tailor’s scissors, chalk, thimble, needle, and a measuring tape. Then he’d cut the cloth, and sit up on the kitchen table before the window, and cross his two legs. He used to sew with the best linen thread.He used to make suits for old men, and little boys, and he used also make sleeve vests for old men, that they used to wear long ago, but they don’t wear them nowadays.
(continues on next page)

4428038/4370998/4474598.title: The Russet Gown and Apron Blue that People Wore Long Ago
4428038/4370998/4474598.text: The Russet Gown the people wore long ago was called the [gobidin]. They made it from dyed flax yarn. it was also used for making inside and outside clothes for growing up girls and children. The part of the yarn that was left in the loom after the [gobidin] cloth was taken away is called the [fuadogs]. They used the [fuadogs] for sewing with. Boys wore this as dresses until they were seven years of age. Long ago the boys and girls used to have their hair cut bare.

4428041/4371606/4474605.title: Rope-Making
4428041/4371606/4474605.text:
In the country the people make straw ropes. A man will thrash the oats out of the straw. Then the man would sit down and let the straw go and another person would be twisting it with a twister, and soon until the rope is made.The hay ropes is made the very same.



In Forge Village, Carrowmore, Ballina, There lived a wheelwright called Pat Collins R.I.P. He used to make spinning wheels, and all parts connected with the wheel. He'd make the body first, and then
(continues on next page)

4428041/4371675/4474783.title: Forges
4428041/4371675/4474783.text:
(continued from previous page)
in the forge, and a hand bellows to light it. he has an anvil a hammer, a sledge, a pincers a vice, a rasp, a chisel, a punch and a steel wedge to cut iron a knife and a large tongs to catch the red iron.



There are two taliors which the people from this district engage. There is one in Killala named Anthony McHale he is deaf and dumb. There is another in Ballygarry, Carrowmore, Lacken, named Tom Connor.Those two taliors are experts, they are talioring since they were boys. Those two taliors make suits coats, and Costumes. They never
(continues on next page)

4428041/4371677/4474784.title: The Tailors
4428041/4371677/4474784.text:
(continued from previous page)
three suits in a week in the Summer days, and about two in the Winter working very hard.



There are five spinning wheels in our district. But only three working . There was a family named Collins in Carrowantransa, Carrowan Lacken that were able to mend spinning wheels. But the father of the family died about two years ago and his son took up his position but he died last year, his name was Pat Collins he was only twenty years of age and he was able to make a spinning wheel in two days. There is no one in the surrounding parishes able to fix his wheels at present. Long ago the women used to start
(continues on next page)

4428041/4371679/4474785.title: (no title)
4428041/4371679/4474785.text: It was after the Christmas and her brother had died on the Xmas night before. He was a very holy man, and she told him to send her some sings if he was happy.So that night she heard a whistle in the Barrow. So she paid no heed. Then she heard a woman singing at the window. So she raked the fire quinched the lamp and went to bed. About a half an hour after wards a beautiful red light came into the house, and filled the house with a beautiful perfume.  So then she knew he was in heaven.

4428042/4371789/4475018.title: Fadó Bhíodh Pisreoga ann mar Leanas

4427977/4363451/4475205.title: Rann
4427977/4363451/4475205.text: (I)" Dá bhfeictheá an táilliúirín aérach'Gus é ag dul amac maidin le fán'Gus a leath-boardín leis ar a ghuailinnIs an t-arann ag bogadh ina láimh(II)" Tá an táilliúirín gan bárr ar a snáth'Gus an figheadóir gan tint ina ceolTa an muillneóir go fán trid na gleanntaIs tá sway le fear na laighe go deo "( Ó Michéal O Móráin, Cill Bridge, Muine Chonláin )

4427977/4363453/4475206.title: Old Song
4427977/4363453/4475206.text:
" Every Monday morning the spinners go to townWith their long burned shins,And their hair hanging down.The thimble makes them yellowAnd the needle makes them thin andYou never saw a spinner without a long burned shin. "



Bhí fear ann fado is fado a bhíDo ceannuigh sé láighe, agus ba deas an laighe íDo bhain sé spreaibín, agus bí neadin faoíBhí uibín ins an neadín is ba dheas an uibhín íBí éinín ins an uibhin is ba dheas an t-éinín í

4428026/4369492/4475462.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428026/4369492/4475462.text:
There are only two tailors working in this district at presant time.They do not go about working in other houses as tailors did in olden times. They do not stock cloth but often get suit lengths home from the mill for customers.Flannelette suits are spun and woven locally. A good many people wear suits spun and woven locally. The only cloth spun and woven locally is flannelette.The implements used by a tailor are a sewingmachine a scissors a Saps thimble a needle a smoothingitoton a lapboard and a tape.Shirts are made in most country house.The coth shirts are made from Flannelette which is
(continues on next page)

4428026/4369494/4475464.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428026/4369494/4475464.text:
There are four tailors in the district. Three of them work in their homes, and one of them travel from house to house when required.One of the tailors stocks cloth. Flannel and blankets are spun, and woven locally. Some people wear clothes made from flannel. A Scissors, an Iron, a needle, a sewing machine, a thimble, and a tape are the tailor's gear.There are very few shirts made in the homes now. About fifty or sixty years ago shirts were made from flax grown locally. Socks and stockings are knitt locally. The thread is spun in nearly every home. There is a spinning wheel in most homes. There are two types of spinning wheels. The flax wheel and the
(continues on next page)

4428026/4369495/4475466.title: Clothes Made Locally
4428026/4369495/4475466.text:
(continued from previous page)
woolen wheel.



There are two or three tailors in this district. Most of those tailors work in their homes. All the tailors stock cloth. Cloth is spun and woven locally. Some people wear suits made of this cloth. This cloth is very warm besides any other cloth. Suits are of different colours.Every tailor has a scissors a sewing machine a tape and a needle.Shirts are made in the homes also. White linen is used when making these shirts.Long ago shirts were made from the flax
(continues on next page)

4428026/4369496/4475468.title: Cloth Made Locally
4428026/4369496/4475468.text:
(continued from previous page)
grown at home. Most of the people grew flax long ago.Socks and stockings are knit locally. The thread is spun in the homes and dyed and stocking are knitt with it.There are differnt spinning wheels such as the small spinning wheel and the big one.The big spinning wheel is worked by hand.



There are several tailors still in the district. They work in their own homes usuall. Seldom we hear of tailors travelling from house to house
(continues on next page)

4428033/4370295/4475517.title: Seancheirdeanna - How Blankets Were Made
4428033/4370295/4475517.text: Long ago the people used not buy blankets like they do now. They used to make the blankets at home out of wool. The women used to spin the wool and make thread out of it. They then gave the thread to a weaver and he used to weave it into blankets. These blankets were very heavy and warm, and were great for wear. Some of them are in the houses yet, and people like them because they are heavy and warm.

4428033/4370415/4475645.title: Éadaí
4428033/4370415/4475645.text:
There were many more tailors in this parish long ago than there are in it now. The peopl used not wear ready-made clothes in those days like they do now, and so the tailor got plenty of work to do. The women used to spin a good deal of thread out of wool. When they had it spun they used to bring it to the weaver to weave it into cloth - called flannel. Then they used to bring it home, and the men used to send for the tailor and he used come and take their measure for the suit. Then he used to wait a week or so in the house until his work
(continues on next page)

4428027/4369700/4475751.title: Éadaí

4428039/4371129/4475761.title: Tailors
4428039/4371129/4475761.text:
There are two Tailors (in this district (which the people engage One in Killala and the other in Bally-garry  Carrowmore. They are very skilful tailors. The Tailor in Killala is called Mr McHale and Mr O Connor  [?] in Ballygarry.Those tailors make suits, coats. They do not keep the cloth themselves. They buy it when they need it. The Killala tailor is deaf and dumb. When the tailor is sewing he sits on a table and crosses his feet. He uses a thimble a
(continues on next page)

4428039/4371133/4475763.title: How Frieze Was Made Long Ago
4428039/4371133/4475763.text:
A pot of water was left beside the fire for such time as the water would be sour. Then they put log wood in to it to colour the water and caprice so that it would not fade afterwards.Then the wool was put into it and boiled on a slow fire for a few days. Then it was squeezed well until all the water was out of it. and washed well in cold water to take any loose dye out of it.After that it was carded and spun then it was sent to the weaver to
(continues on next page)

4428039/4371224/4475932.title: How Candles Were Made Long Ago
4428039/4371224/4475932.text:
First the rushes were picked and then skinned. Then they were matted together. The tallow was left beside the fire to rinder. When it was rindered the matted rushes were dipped in it. A knitting pin was put through it. It was left for sometime to set. Then a stout piece of cord was put in it and in this way light was provided.



A pot of water was left beside the fire for such time as the water would be sour. Then they put logwood into it to colour the water and coprice so that its colour would not fade afterwards.
(continues on next page)

4428035/4370628/4476273.title: Hata Bhaile Gleanna
4428035/4370628/4476273.text: Men's hats were so scarce one time that there was only one in Ballinglen. A cabin was made for it near Mrs Scott's, Glenedagh. A man, when going to town, used to wear it and leave it back when he returned. All the villagers used it on turns. It was known as hsrs baile Jlesnns.

4428027/4369738/4476347.title: Teach an Táilliúra
4428027/4369738/4476347.text:
Bhí am níos mó ná céad bliadhain ó shoin ní raibh tada ag na tailliúir acht ag imthracht ó therach go teach ag déanamh éadaigh in a shuidhe ar an leith-dhoras ag fuagháil agus ag coingbheáil na gcearc as nba garrdhannta. Dá mbeadg níos mó ná soitheach amháin go gach coingbheáil sa teach ag na daoinibh dheireadh na daoine "Ní h-é teach an tailliúra é" mar nach raibh an dara soitheach ag an táilliúir bocht.



I bhfad ó shoin bhí go léor cluichí ag na páistí. Bhíodh na buachaillí ag caitheamh léim, ag caitheamh urchar cloch, ag coraidheacht, ag tógáilt a chéile ar ghreim, iosaic, ag bualadh
(continues on next page)
