4921879/4898137/5195483.title: Béaloideas
4921879/4898137/5195483.text: Long ago there lived a shoemaker not far from my house. His name was Patrick Kelly. He used to make boots for all the people. He would go to each house and make the boots. He would stay about three weeks or a month in each house as he would make four or five pairs of boots at the time. They would supply the leather and he would make the boots. During his time people never wore boots until they were nearly twenty years of age as they thought the feet were alot healthier without shoes. At that time the people always wore hand made boots. He used to make clogs also for the men.
4921879/4898137/5195483.school_info: School: Teampoll na Carraige,  Mainistir na Corann

5170144/5169489/5195598.title: The Care of the Feet
5170144/5169489/5195598.text:
In olden times the people did not know how to take care of their feet. They wore tight boots and their toes were on top of each other and that caused corns and bunions to grown on their feet and that is the reason why old peoples feet are deformed. Nowadays people get a pair of boots too big for them so as to have room in them. Old people say Dont buy tight boots for Sunday or Monday. Because if you do you will regret it someday.

5170141/5169183/5196298.title: Clothes Made Locally
5170141/5169183/5196298.text:
There are three tailors residing in Arva. Each of them works in his own house. They do not stock cloth. When a person wants a suit he buys the cloth in a draper's shop and then brings it to the tailor. No cloth is made locally. It is got from the mills. The cloth generally used for suits is tweed and serge. The implements used by the tailors are a needle, thimble, sewing machine chalk, pressing board and iron. One of the tailors has an electric sewing machine. Shirts are made by some women in Arva. Long ago shirts were made from flax grown locally. The flax was scutched sometimes by hand & sometimes in the mill. Then it was spun into thread which was taken to a bleach green near Scarvey Bridge in the townland of Lacken 3 miles from Arva. When the the thread was bleached it was taken home. The
(continues on next page)

4921806/4908944/5196696.title: Clothes Made Locally
4921806/4908944/5196696.text: There are nine tailors in this district. They only work in their homes. They don't travel from place to place working. They stock cloth in their own homes.The cloth is neither spun nor woven locally. The tailors implements are:- a timble, a scissors, needles, and threads, a sewing machine, an iron. Shirts are not made locally, but stockings are knitted.All wedding clothes are made by tailors. Ladies whose relatives have died usually wear black, but men very often wear only a black armlet or diamond.

5170150/5170085/5197037.title: Care of the Feet
5170150/5170085/5197037.text:
(continued from previous page)
and Mary Reburn who were Henry Rebrun's uncles and aunts of Kespanduff made and repaired boots. Maggie Duffy's father called John McMahon of Cootehill kept a tanning yard in Bridge Street about fifty years ago. Frank McKeon's father also kept a tanning yard in the same street.



Three women and two men makes clothes in their own homes for the neighbours in this district. About sixty five years ago Micheal Clarke, Tunnyduf travelled about this district and often spent two or three weeks in my grand-
(continues on next page)

5170150/5170087/5197038.title: Clothes Made Locally
5170150/5170087/5197038.text:
To-day there are two or three local tailors Patrick McCann of Drumaveil and John Sheirdan of Larganboy. These two work in their own houses. The tailor Crosson of Drumaveil who made clothes for my father long ago and the tailor Tegan of Killarue worked in the houses for whom they sewed. In Brian McCann's house of Killatee there was an old spinning wheel till about ten years ago. It became rotton and broke away. There are not many houses that shirts are made in now. When my father was a young boy, his mother made all
(continues on next page)

4921776/4906116/5197370.title: Clothes Made Locally
4921776/4906116/5197370.text:
There are only two local tailors in Banteer district at present. Timothy Kiely of Banteer, and Patrick OSullivan of Rathcoole, Banteer. Patrick Sullivan does the greater part of his work travelling from house to house, and has to be supplied with all materials. Timothy Kiely works in his shop, and has one assistant employed. He keeps a stock of tweeds in his shop. These he purchases from the Cork merchants. The local journeymen tailors in the district in old days were Jeremiah Murphy, Inchidaly, Banteer, Jerry Murphy, Kilcorney, Banteer, James Dunne, Lyre, Banteer, Con Murphy, Kilmacrane, Banteer, and James Wilkinson, Banteer. They never furnished the materials. Their kit consisted of needles, scissors, lop board, pressing iron, thimbles, chalk and measuring tape. The material was usually bought at Kanturk, or at Blackwater Woollen Mills, Rosnalee, Banteer. In some cases the cloth was made at home from wool, and called "Frieze". The price charged for making a suit was about nine shillings, but the tailor always had to be supplied with his food. Shirts were made from grey calico, which was first bleached. The fronts, and cuffs, were finished with white linen. Socks were made from home-spun thread. The late Mrs James Twohig, of Tureen, Banteer was an expert at this work. She also
(continues on next page)

5162130/5156646/5197516.title: Clothes Made Locally
5162130/5156646/5197516.text:
The only tailor in this district is James Duggan. He does not travel from house to house but works at home. The tailor does not stock cloth but he keeps patterns.Cloth is not spun or woven in this district.I do not know any traditions connected with tailors or tailoring. The tailor uses a scissors, tape, needle, machine, and a board or table for cutting out the material on.Shirts are not made in this district. Linen sheeting and table-cloths are made from flax but not in this district. Socks and stockings are sometimes knitted.
(continues on next page)

5162128/5156469/5197714.title: Clothes Made Locally
5162128/5156469/5197714.text: About twenty years ago there lived a tailor in Ballycarron in the parish of Kilmoyler.  His name was Daniel O'Connell but he was always called 'Daneen'.  He was not much of a tailor, but still it was he who used to make all the clothes for the people of the district.  Whatever he made did not turn out as the way people wanted it, and they used to say ''it isn't what you would ask him to make he would make at all''.  His son is a school teacher and his daughters are still alive.
5162128/5156469/5197714.school_info: School: Ceathair Dhúin Iascaigh, Clochar na Trócaire

5162149/5158908/5197922.title: Story about Cobblers
5162149/5158908/5197922.text: About forty years ago a large amount of cobblers use to pay a visit to Fahy’s field Windgap Carrickbeg, Carrick – on- Suir and they used to take an oath by taking an awl in their right hand and they use to swear that one cobbler would not sell a shoe or boot cheaper or dearer within the future twelve months. They used to stick an awl into the tree when taking the oath. The tree widered away and the trunk of the tree remains up to the present day. It is left there in memory of the old cobblers that came from  Carrick – on- Suir  to stick their awls in to Fahy’s Elm tree. When the cobblers used to come out to Fahy’s field they used to make a whip from strips of leather and they used to whip tops along the road until they reach the field. The field is called the Court field because the cobblers used to take oaths in this field.
5162149/5158908/5197922.school_info: School: An Charraig Bheag, Carraig na Siúire

5162152/5159103/5198526.title: The Man Who Lives in a Rock
5162152/5159103/5198526.text:
(continued from previous page)
He eats porridge for his breakfast. He has a straw bed.



There was a shoemaker living near the village of Ballythomas, Co. Waterford about fifty years ago. His name was Paddy Fitzgerald. There was a patch on some part of his face and he was known as Paddy the Patch. it was said about him that he never made a pair of boots or shoes big enough for anybody and so all who went to have their measure taken wore two pairs of stockings so that Paddy would think they had bigger feet. The ruins of his house are on Martin Walshe's farm, Ballythomas.



There was a strong man named Patrick Walsh living in Ballingarra in the Co. Waterford. He did many brave deeds.
(continues on next page)
5162152/5159103/5198526.school_info: School: Ráth Ó gCormaic (C.), Carraig na Siúire

5162152/5159180/5198653.title: Éadaí
5162152/5159180/5198653.text:
There is a tailor named Edmond Daly in Park, Co. Waterford. He makes clothes for men and coats for women. He does not go around to the houses to work but works in his own house. The people bring the material to him from town and and they make lining from flour-bags. The tools he has are - a scissors, and a thimble, a needle, a tape-measure, an iron, a pipe-clay to mark the pattern on the cloth, a lapboard which he holds in his lap pressing the suit, a bone for ripping tacking threads, a ruler, a machine and a pencil and note book to take down the measurements. There is no end in the thimble he has.  When the people bring the stuff he takes their measure and they have to fit it on afterwards. He charges sixteen shillings or a pound to make a suit. There is a piseóg about the cutting out of a suit. Any tailors does not cut out a suit on a Monday because long ago it was thought to be unlucky and the old custom is still kept. There was a man named Peter Spillane going around sewing and mending clothes to the houses in Curraghkiely but he does not go around now because he is too old and is not able to walk. We have a machine at home and we buy the material in Carrick-on-Suir and we make all our own clothes. When a person dies in a house the people generally wear black clothes. Children
(continues on next page)
5162152/5159180/5198653.school_info: School: Ráth Ó gCormaic (C.), Carraig na Siúire

5162152/5159181/5198654.title: Éadaí
5162152/5159181/5198654.text:
(continued from previous page)
wear wreaths and veils and white dresses receiving first Holy Communion and Confirmation.



Tailors. There are two tailors in this Parish. Their names are Jim Cleary and Ned Daly. They work at home. People buy the material and bring it to them. There is an old saying, "Nine tailors make a man" which means that tailors are no men.Dressmakers. There are two dressmakers in the parish. Their names are Bridgie Roe and Mollie Power. They do not make shirts. They charge 10 shillings to make a costume and 12 shillings to make a coat. My sister knits jumpers. She buys the thread in Carrick, and a woman named Minnie Guilly knits our school stockings. My sister knits scarves. There is no spinning wheel used now. I never saw one but there was one in my house long long ago. There are special clothes for special occasions. For weddings, the bride wears a long frock. Black clothes are worn when there is a death in the family. All white is worn for Confirmation and Holy Communion. Sometimes we buy our clothes in town. Flour bags are very useful. The flour can be washed out of them and then they can be made out into sheets and other things. Kitty Phelan, Carrowleigh. Rathgormack.Tailors. There are two tailors in the parish of Rathgormack. Their names are Edmond Daly and James Cleary. They make
(continues on next page)

5162139/5157858/5198795.title: Clothes
5162139/5157858/5198795.text:
There is a great difference between the clothes the people wore long ago and the clothes they wear nowadays.The men wore overcaots made of frieze. The tailor came round to the houses in a horse car and made the coat for a few shilling's. It had a long tail at the end and it was called a swallow tail coat. When going to Mass the men wore corduroy trousers fastened at the knee and they wore long stockings to cover the rest of their feet.The shirts the men wore were made of hard linen and they were very uncomfortable. They also wore high collars with fronts on them and black ties.The women were dressed different to the men. They wore red petticoats and black home knit shawls. When they were going to Mass they wore black hodded coats and shoes with timber soles called clogs. The women
(continues on next page)

5177620/5173702/5198949.title: Forges
5177620/5173702/5198949.text:
(continued from previous page)
welcome for all who drop in and it is very seldom that it is not full up. Every man and boy who happens to pass the way drop in for a chat and a good yarn. It is very unlucky to steal anything out of a forge and it is also unlucky to put a beast into it at night. There is a cure for warts in the water that is kept in a forge. The implements that are used in the forge are a sledge, pincers, hammer, rasp and tongs.



There are four tailors in this parish, they are :- Mr. John Liddy, Mr. John Moloney, Mr. Joseph Leonard and Mr. James Sammon. Long ago the tailors used to go from house to house and sometimes they used to stay in a country house for about a week making clothes for all the household. Each year the people used to make frieze and flannel
(continues on next page)

5177626/5174037/5200326.title: Éadaí
5177626/5174037/5200326.text:
At the present time there is no tailor in the parish of Bodyke but long ago there was one in the village of Bodyke called Denny Hogan.  He was married to a woman from Galway who had the habit of using the word "Masha" very often and she was never called outside of her own hearing but "Masha."Denny used to sew with the hand.  He was not very good - no bond sheet cut about him.  There were dressmakers in the parish who had no real training but natural training in themselves.Most of the woman now can make well for the girls while they are young.Every woman knitted the dockers, stockings used by the men and children.Today, that industry of knitting is well developed socks - stockings, cardigans, jumpers, pullovers, boys and girls knitted suits.Some of the women in the parish can make any kind of frock.  Coat etc with the aid of patterns.  There is a sewing machine in nearly every house where the woman is handy.  The people say that this gift follows in families and of the mother is good the girls will also be good.When I was young the farmers daughters wore frocks made of flannel (home made and dyed).
(continues on next page)

5177630/5174326/5201027.title: (no title)
5177630/5174326/5201027.text: 276           29.Flax was grown in the district up to about 60 years ago.it was manufactured in the home ,and shirts ,bed-linen and table-linen were made from it. The coarser and rougher portion was used for towels .In some of the streams ,ponds are still pointed out as the "flax-holes" of those days where the flax used be soaked previous to "pounding".

5162109/5154942/5201125.title: Tailors
5162109/5154942/5201125.text:
There is only one tailor in my district.  He makes clothes for all the people in the locality.  He never stocks the material.  When a person wants to get a suit made, he buys the material in a clothes shop and then he goes to the tailor to make it.     Long ago the tailors used go about from house to house to make clothes for the people.  It was not by the suit these tailors were paid but by the day.  The instruments used by a tailor are; sewing machine, needles, thread, a goose iron, a measure, a scissors, and a thimble.     Shirts and all our underwear are made at home.  My mother makes our coats, costumes and our frocks.  We also knit pullovers,cardigans, and socks.  The shirts that were made long ago were made from calico and linen.  The bodies were made from calico, and the cuffs and fronts were made from linen.  The collar was a standing up one with two left down peaks.  A black tie used to be worn with these collars.  The linen parts of these shirts used be starched.  These were called

5177630/5174363/5201212.title: Frieze
5177630/5174363/5201212.text: 313            Frieze.The wool was washed on the sheeps back and then shorn.The fleece was then put into a pot of water with alder branches through it and kept.boiling for 24 hrs to "rime"it.It was then taken up ,the branches picked out and put back into the "rime"water with log- wood and capper as (this was bought in the shops)to be dyed black-this was the only colour in those days.A portion of the fleece was dyed blue with "Indigo"(something like bluestone).Some blue ,black and white wools were then teased and mixed and oiled (with rape oil).The wool was then "carded" (made into rools)with hand cards,spun with a  large woollen wheel,then warped and woven.It was then taken to a tuck -mil land tucked,(thickened) this shortened it about 1/3 each way ,(length and Width ).It  was then ready for the tailor to make it into over-coats frock -coats and body-coats.

5177630/5174364/5201213.title: Scouring of Frieze
5177630/5174364/5201213.text: Urine was collected for the week previous. It was heated and poured on the frieze or flannel in a tub and a heavy man or woman used to poss [?] it with their bare feet. A chair was placed at the side of the tub abd the poerson danced on it to remove the grease. The liquid was changed several times and soap was added in the final washing.  It was not used at the beginning on account of its milling properties.  It was then taken up, rinced well and hung out to dry.

5162142/5158306/5203074.text: There is only one tailor in this Parish. He works at home. No tailor goes around now. They do not have clothes for sale. There are no clothes woven in the parish now. There was clothes woven in the parish long ago. There are shirts made. The tailor uses a machine, a scissors, a thimble, and a needle and thread. The shirts are made of flannelette. 5162142/5158307/5203076.title: Éadaí
5162142/5158307/5203076.text: There is only one tailor in this parish. He lives and works in Doonbeg. He never has clothes for sale. No cloth is woven in this parish now. There was woven cloth in this parish about ten years ago. The weaver's name was Normoyle. The implements a tailor has are, a sewing machine, an iron, a scissors, a thimble, a needle, and a measure. 5162142/5158313/5203083.title: Éadaí
5162142/5158313/5203083.text: I know of only one tailor in the parish. He works at his trade in his own house. He is not usual for them to have clothes for sale except on rare occasions. No clothes are woven in the parish now. There were clothes woven in the parish up to three years ago. The weaver was Mr. Nomyhe. The implements a tailor uses at his trade are, a bench, a machine, a measure, a needle, a scissors, thread and a thimble. Shirts are made in some houses. They are made of flannelette. Stocking are knitted also. There are a good many spinning wheels in this locality. Most of the thread is bought in the shops, but some of it is spun at home.

5162142/5158314/5203084.title: Éadaí

5162144/5158494/5203349.text:
They used to have three meals in the day which consisted of potatoes and Indian meal stirabout, milk, butter, eggs and some times fish. The clothes they used to wear were frieze coats and corduroy trousers and once every three or five years they used get a suit and strong home made linen shirts and strong home made leather shoes and long knitted stockings.

5162144/5158521/5203409.title: Customs at Wakes Long Ago
5162144/5158521/5203409.text:
Long ago, it was customary at wakes to give both men and women tobacco, clay pipes, and snuff. Also long ago they used to pay old women to cry at funerals.



Long ago the people used to bring the clothes to a pond and wash them, then lay them down on top of a flag and beat them with a timber bittle. Then lay them on the grass for two or three days to bleach.

5162134/5157163/5215996.title: Feet Water
5162134/5157163/5215996.text: 496              Feet Water.The young people in this parish go barefooted in Summer.At night they wash their feet before going to bed in lukewarm water .This water is immediately thrown out as it is considered unlucky to leave it inside over the night.My grandmother told me that in a certain house in the parish there was a lazy woman who thought it too much trouble to throw out the feet water .She left it under the table and went to bed .In the middle of the night she was awakened by a loud noise in the kitchen and she thought she heard someone say "Get up and throw out the feet water"She did so .From that night on she never failed to throw out the water when the children had their feet washed.

At the present time tailors do all their work in their own houses. They still sit on the table crosslegged. About 40 years ago the tailor always worked where the suit was wanted. He sat on the table and boarded and lodged where he worked. He sang and talked while he worked and was the news carrier of the district. Johnny Duggan flourished about 50 or 60 years ago. He lived on the Old Road. The tailor always brought his own lap-board. Gabha Snáth was the thread used. The wool fair was in the month of July.After the wool was bought it was slámed. 5260407/5250083/5262299.text:
There are two tailors in this district they work in their homes now but in olden times they went to the houses making clothes for the people. In olden times the people used to make their clothes by spinning the wool and getting the thread woven into cloth. In olden times the people used to wear cloth called frieze. The tailors use a needle a thimble scissors an iron and an iron board. In olden times the people used
(continues on next page)

5260445/5253036/5262999.title: Clothes
5260445/5253036/5262999.text: Long ago the men used wear knee breeches buckled below the knee with six brass buttons. They had coat called a cut away frieze coat or a swallow tail coat. and a caroline hate and cane. The wemon had a red flannen skirt a plaid shawl and a red hand ketchief around their heads and a check apron.They then put a bog hoop in on the top of their skirt to make it rise out all around.

5260488/5259172/5263125.title: Clothes
5260488/5259172/5263125.text:
There are five tailors in this parish  There is one on Dooey one in Madavaugh and three in Dungloe. They all work in their own homes. They dont go from house to house as they used to do. The people round here dont wear homespun cloth now. The women knit stockings sometimes but gloves are the most thing that are knit.When the women

5260488/5259328/5263203.title: Tailors
5260488/5259328/5263203.text: Bryan Molloy could make a pair of trousers while a half penny candle would be burning. Ned T Gallagher could make a pair of breeches in a day - all hand work. Pat Mc Glynn could make a suit of flannel in a day all hand work.Paddy Dugan could make an over coat in four hours.Frank Hearne could make a suit when he was ninety years.

5260488/5259493/5263357.title: Tailors
5260488/5259493/5263357.text:
Five tailors that are in this district. The tailors work at home.Some of the tailors keep their own cloth.All the tools the tailors have are a machine a tape a sissors an iron a thimble and needles.This is an old saying. It takes nine tailors to make a man.

5260488/5259762/5265276.title: Old Tailors
5260488/5259762/5265276.text: Jack Terrel was a good tailor. He worked in Ireland, England and Scotland. Con Bonnor. He could finish a suit in two days - all hand - work. Jack Austin was a good tailor. He could make a suit in a day.Frank Hearne could make a suit when he was ninty years. All these were tailors who went round about the place.

5260471/5256249/5275234.title: Local Tailors
5260471/5256249/5275234.text: There are many tailor in Ireland. In olden times, cloaths were made hand now they are made by machines. Clothing is made from sheep's wool mixed with cotton. The cloath is still spun in Donegal. The girls gather the flax and spin it into cloths. Tailors in other places make cloath out of the cloth that is made by michans.

In Kilcullen there are three tailors. Long ago both stockings and shirts were made in this area. One woman has still a machine to make stockings and I think she make some still. Her  name is Mrs. Lambe. Mrs Lambe also knits Irish lace.

In Kilcullen there are two tailors who make suits of clothes. There is also a woman who has a machine for making thread she knits stockings with the thread and then sells them in the country houses at reasonable prices. Stockings are made in the homes by the idle girls. They also knit pullovers. Boys trousers are also made by the women. There is no one in this district has spinning wheels or remembers them. There is only one tailor in this locality named Domnick Gavan. He does not get much work to do. There is a tailor in Balla named McNamara who does a bigger trade.



There is no fair held in the locality at present. At one time there was a pig fair held at Kearn's Cross Road in the village of Tavanagh parish of Straide.The nearest fair which is held now-a-days is held in Balla.

5215784/5210015/5278408.title: Tailor
5215784/5210015/5278408.text: There is a tailor in the townland of Loughill, Parish of Straide, who makes clothes. He has a scissors and a thimble. When men want a new suit they go to the tailor and leave their measurements to him and the tailor takes his scissors and cuts out the suit. Then he bastes it with a needle and thread and he puts a thimble on his finger. When he has the suit basted he sews it on the machine. After two or three days the suit of clothes is finished and ready for wearing.

5215784/5210199/5278493.title: Tailors
5215784/5210199/5278493.text: There are not many tailors around here. There is a tailor in the town of Balla named Phil Heneghan. He has a few workers always working in the house sewing as he gets a lot of work to do. It takes about two days to make a man's suit.

5215784/5210319/5278616.title: Tailors
5215784/5210319/5278616.text: Long ago there lived in our village a tailor named Reilly. This tailor used to make clothes for every one. He had a sowing machine.

5009123/4988574/5278981.title: Notes - Ethnographic
5009123/4988574/5278981.text: 70 or 80 years ago as there was no soap made or too dear to buy people used urine as a bleacher for clothes - usually linen - which was bleached, fairly widespread in the district. It (the  urine) was supposed to be kept three weeks before it was used.

5215784/5210507/5279069.title: Clothing and Food in Days Gone By
5215784/5210507/5279069.text:
In times gone when people got up in the morning they first said their prayers then they went to the field to work and did all the morning jobs before getting a breakfast. They got for breakfast potatoes and milk or stirabout and milk. If milk wasn't plentiful in the homes they used "sound shearins" that was oatmeal and seeds of oats steeped in a crock for a week and when it got sour people used it instead of milk.The kind of bread they used was

He was never called but "Micheal an tailliúir."He used to make suits for all people round the place. 5275203/5272369/5283587.text:
There is only tailor around this district and he is named Mr. Townsend of Dunnamaggin and there is one tailoress named Mrs O Brien Kellsboro.Mr Townsend always works at his own house.This man makes suits of clothes for men and boys, out of blue serge, and also out of tweed material.Mrs O Brien can make coats and costumes for women and girls, and that woman always works at her home.
